7) As the Bitcoin blockchain becomes bigger and more complex, there are only two logical conclusions. The first is that a single miner ends up effectively owning the Bitcoin blockchain, and thereby the currency (“winner-takes-all”).

4) The problem lies in mining, participants in the blockchain that confirm transactions and write them into a general ledger. Miners undertake to add transactions to the Bitcoin blockchain by solving mathematical puzzles, a process known as proof-of-work, in return for payment.

3a/ Foundation funded by one time allocation in token sale. Foundation pays salaries and/or open bounties. Can be centralized (most common today) or decentralized. Example: Ethereum. Upsides: simple, expert curation in early days. Downsides: limited bounties, runs out eventually.

2/ Private funding. Large holders, companies/projects building on the chain, or open crowdfunds create programs to pay for development. Example: Bitcoin. Upsides: simple, decentralized. Downsides: tragedy of the commons.
